unnormalised: The monsoons had always been a spectacle in Kerala. I remember Amma checking the IMD website religiously every year around May, prepping for the inevitable downpour. This year, 2024, felt different though. The website predicted an “early monsoon” arriving on 28/05/2024, a whole week ahead of schedule.
normalised: The monsoons had always been a spectacle in Kerala. I remember Amma checking the I-M-D website religiously every year around May, prepping for the inevitable downpour. This year, two thousand and twenty four, felt different though. The website predicted an “early monsoon” arriving on twenty eighth May two thousand and twenty four, a whole week ahead of schedule.

unnormalised: And it did arrive, with a vengeance. The first week of June saw unprecedented rainfall. The local news channels were flashing warnings – “Red alert in Ernakulam, Idukki, Pathanamthitta till 07/06/2024, expect 200mm+ rainfall”. Appa, usually calm, was glued to the TV, muttering about the rising water levels in the Periyar river. He prepone-d his trip to Kochi to 06/06/2024 to oversee his business interests, earlier than the originally planned 10/06/2024.

Appa, usually calm, was glued to the T-V, muttering about the rising water levels in the Periyar river. He preponed his trip to Kochi to sixth June two thousand and twenty four to oversee his business interests, earlier than the originally planned tenth June two thousand and twenty four.

unnormalised: My cousin, Priya, studying in Chennai, called worried. She had a flight back home scheduled for 12/06/2024. “Will the airport be open?” she fretted. I checked the airport’s website, which vaguely stated “possible delays” and advised passengers to check flight status 4 hours before departure. Not very reassuring, I thought. She eventually managed to book her tickets to 13/06/2024 evening after an hour on the phone.

unnormalised: The weatherman on DD News declared a “slight respite” from 15/06/2024. “The low-pressure area over the Arabian Sea is weakening. Expect scattered showers, but not the torrential downpour of the past two weeks.” I hoped he was right. The constant rain had been depressing, and even the chai seemed less comforting than usual.

unnormalised: However, by the 20th of June, the rain returned, albeit less intensely. The forecast for the next 72 hours indicated “moderate rainfall, with chances of thunderstorms in the evenings.” The local MLA even suggested cloud seeding at 16:00 hrs to make the weather more controlled, but that was quickly dismissed.

unnormalised: Amma, ever the optimist, still pointed out the positives. “The reservoirs are full,” she said. “At least we won't have water scarcity this year. The Kerala State Electricity Board expects hydropower production to reach record levels in Q3 2024, as a result."

unnormalised: By the end of June, as I write this, the forecast seems to be settling into a pattern: partly cloudy skies during the day, followed by evening showers. The long-range forecast suggests a gradual decrease in rainfall intensity from 01/07/2024 onward. Fingers crossed, maybe this monsoon season won't be as apocalyptic as it started out. After all, Kerala needs its sunshine too.
